name: Louvre
description: A one-hour highlights tour optimized for minimal walking: Denon Wing Level 1 ‘grands formats,’ Galerie d’Apollon, and the Salle des États.
introTranscript: Welcome to a focused highlight run through the Louvre. We’ll climb the Daru Staircase to meet Winged Victory, glide through the monumental French canvases, walk the glittering Galerie d’Apollon, and finish with a moment before the Mona Lisa—maximum art, minimal backtracking.

stops.title: Winged Victory of Samothrace (Nike)
stops.description: Hellenistic marble of the goddess Nike, staged dramatically atop the Daru Staircase landing.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take your time with this one—she rewards a slow look. You’re standing before the Winged Victory of Samothrace, also called Nike, carved around 200–190 BCE by an unknown Hellenistic sculptor. She originally stood on the island of Samothrace, in the Sanctuary of the Great Gods, as a gleaming offering to commemorate a naval victory—very likely by a seafaring power such as Rhodes. Imagine the salt air and the sound of oars: this wasn’t just art, it was a thank-you to the gods for triumph at sea.

What you’re seeing is the very moment a goddess lands on the prow of a warship. Nike’s body twists powerfully, her chest lifted, her weight driving forward. A sudden wind seems to strike her—see how the marble clings to her abdomen and thigh like wet fabric, then whips into deep, fluttering folds at her back? That’s the famous Hellenistic love of drama and motion: a body revealed and concealed at once. The wings arch out, enormous and muscular. Note the difference between them—one preserves more ancient carving, while the other is largely a modern restoration, mirroring its mate so we can feel the full spread.

Look down at the base: it’s a ship’s prow, not an abstract pedestal. That darker, grey marble comes from Lartos on Rhodes, while the statue herself is cut from luminous Parian marble. The prow’s lines—sharp, slicing—anchor the sculpture’s flight in something real, so you can almost hear the hull cutting through waves. In her original setting, the monument was positioned high and theatrically; placing her at the head of a grand staircase today echoes that soaring approach, so you meet her as ancient worshippers might have—looking up, swept by her momentum.

A little secret: for a long time, people imagined she held a trumpet. But fragments of her right hand, found on Samothrace in 1950 and reunited with the statue’s story, show an open palm. No instrument—just a victorious gesture, as if she’s proclaiming, “We did it,” with the wind for a voice. And yes, the head and arms are missing, but notice how the sculpture doesn’t feel incomplete. Your eye fills in the rest, carried by the force of that landing.

If you want a broader thread to hold onto, think of this as ancient cinema carved in stone. Hellenistic artists were masters of the “action shot,” and Nike is the genre’s superstar—movement, sound, and atmosphere made visible. Two thousand years later, she still makes us lean forward, breathe in, and feel the lift of victory. Let her wind catch you, just for a moment, and imagine the spray of the sea. That’s the triumph she was born to deliver.
stops.artistTranscript:
You’ve met the superstar. Now, a word about the maker—whoever they were. The Winged Victory comes from the high Hellenistic world, when Greek sculptors were fearless about drama, movement, and theater. Our artist’s name is lost, but their “voice” comes through loud and clear: a sculptor trained in a bustling Aegean workshop—very likely connected to the island networks that supplied major sanctuaries—who specialized in turning wind, water, and speed into stone.

Hellenistic sculptors worked like filmmakers and engineers combined. A master designed the pose and overall effect; assistants roughed out blocks; specialists cut drapery and feathers; the master finished the crucial surfaces. For a monument like this, the sculptor planned not just a figure, but an experience: how the form reads from a distance, from below, and in motion as viewers approach. Those deep undercuts and bold silhouettes aren’t just virtuosity—they’re stagecraft, meant to catch light and cast fast-moving shadows so your eye feels momentum.

Technically, it’s a feat. Large marbles were built from multiple pieces, pinned together with metal dowels and sealed with lead. Different chisels and drills created channels of shadow in the folds; then abrasives—often emery from the Greek islands—smoothed skin to a soft glow while leaving the drapery crisper so it would sparkle. And remember, many Hellenistic marbles carried touches of added color or metal fittings; sculptors thought in mixed media long before that had a name.

You may hear people credit a specific Rhodian master for works like this—Pythokritos’ name is sometimes floated—but there’s no secure evidence. Scholars keep the authorship anonymous, and that anonymity tells us something: in this period, the glory of a dedication often belonged to the city and the gods, while the workshop’s craft spoke for itself.

Why is this unknown sculptor remembered? Because they helped redefine what marble could do—making atmosphere and velocity visible—and set a model that later artists, from Roman copyists to Baroque masters, chased in their own ways.

If you want a human connection, imagine the carver’s day: hands chalked with stone dust, listening for the clean ring of the chisel, backing up again and again to see if the figure “breathes.” We don’t have a signature, but in the choices—the daring cuts, the careful polish—you can still meet the person who trusted rock to carry a gust of wind across two millennia.

stops.title: The Raft of the Medusa — Théodore Géricault
stops.description: A colossal, visceral canvas of survival and politics after the 1816 shipwreck.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take a slow step back and let your eyes adjust to the scale of this thing. You’re standing before Théodore Géricault’s The Raft of the Medusa, painted in 1818–1819, and it’s almost five meters high and over seven meters wide. It’s the size of a wall—and that’s no accident. Géricault wanted a contemporary tragedy to have the grandeur of a classical epic.

Here’s the story. In 1816, the French naval frigate Méduse ran aground off the coast of West Africa, largely due to an incompetent captain appointed through political favor. In the chaos, a makeshift raft carried 147 people; after nearly two weeks adrift—storms, starvation, even cannibalism—only 15 survived. The scandal rocked France. Just a few years later, at age twenty-seven, Géricault chose this as his subject. He interviewed survivors like the surgeon Henri Savigny and the engineer Alexandre Corréard, built a model of the raft in his studio, and studied human anatomy relentlessly—even in the morgue—to get the truth of bodies under extreme duress. He unveiled the painting at the Salon of 1819, where it shocked and mesmerized the public.

Now, what are you seeing? Let your gaze travel from the lower left: a tangle of lifeless and exhausted bodies, their skin ash-gray or waxen, the sea slick against the boards. An older man cradles the corpse of a youth—often read as a father and son—a contemporary echo of a Pietà. The diagonal sweeps upward across the raft: bodies rouse, arms lift, a tattered sail strains, and a wet wind catches the figures like a wave. At the apex, a Black sailor—often identified as Jean Charles by later accounts—stands and thrashes a cloth to signal a tiny speck on the horizon. Look carefully, toward the right: that minuscule silhouette is the Argus, the ship that will eventually rescue them. It’s heartbreakingly far away.

Géricault builds two powerful diagonals that cross the canvas: one of despair, from the dead and dying; the other of hope, cresting toward that flicker of salvation. The palette is all storm—olive greens, tar blacks, bruised flesh, and honeyed light breaking through the clouds. The sea is not just a setting; it’s a character, heaving those bodies upward in a last surge of life. Every figure is individualized—no anonymous heroism here—and yet together they form a living pyramid of human will.

A detail you might have missed: the man in the extreme foreground, face down with an arm flung toward us, is said to have been modeled by Géricault’s friend, the young Eugène Delacroix. Imagine the future painter of Liberty Leading the People stretched out on the studio floor, holding that pose while Géricault worked.

This painting changed the rules. History painting had traditionally celebrated gods, kings, and ancient myths. Géricault used that same monumental format to confront a very recent, very political disaster—and to hold power to account. It also marks a turning point toward Romanticism: art that privileges emotion, nature’s sublime force, and the raw truth of lived experience.

Before you move on, take one last look at the horizon. The Argus is barely there—hope is a dot. Yet every muscle, every gust of wind, every splinter in this raft surges toward it. It’s a reminder that art can place us right at the edge between despair and deliverance, and ask, with brutal honesty: what does it mean to keep signaling, to keep waving, when help is only a speck?
stops.artistTranscript:
Meet Théodore Géricault: born in Rouen in 1791, blazing through Paris in the early 1800s, and gone by thirty-two—yet he helped launch French Romanticism. He was a rider, a risk-taker, and a painter obsessed with energy and emotion. Trained by Carle Vernet, the great horse painter, and the classical master Pierre-Narcisse Guérin, he spent hours copying Rubens and Michelangelo in the Louvre. That mix—muscular drawing, dramatic light, and a hunger for the present moment—became his signature.

Watch his early career and you can feel his compass shifting. In 1812, his Officer of the Imperial Guard charges out of the frame, all Napoleonic swagger; by 1814, his Wounded Cuirassier limps away, the bravado cracking into vulnerability. After a messy family scandal and a spell in Italy, Géricault came back determined to treat modern life with the weight usually reserved for myth—soldiers returning from war, working horses, people pushed to the margins.

That conviction sits right behind the painting you’ve just heard about: taking a story of his own time and giving it epic gravity. It wasn’t a stunt; it was his belief that contemporary lives mattered on the grand stage.

He kept pushing. In 1820, he brought that massive canvas to London, where crowds queued to see it. He stayed on, studying British sporting art and embracing the new medium of lithography—turning out vivid prints of racehorses, boxers, and street life. Back in Paris, he painted the small, piercing series now called Portraits of the Insane, portraying psychiatric patients with startling dignity rather than caricature. That human focus influenced Delacroix directly, and later artists like Courbet looked to Géricault as a bridge to modern, socially engaged painting.

A small surprise: if you visit Père Lachaise Cemetery in Paris, his tomb carries a bronze relief of that storm-tossed raft—as if his great subject keeps vigil over him.

Géricault’s life was dramatic—brilliant early success, personal turmoil, and health ruined by riding accidents—but what lingers is his empathy. He looked at the speed, strain, and injustice of his own era and insisted it deserved the scale of history. Remember him not just as a painter of spectacle, but as a person who took people seriously.

stops.title: Liberty Leading the People — Eugène Delacroix
stops.description: Iconic emblem of the July Revolution of 1830; allegory strides through real Parisian fighters.
stops.artworkTranscript:
All right, take a small step back and let your eyes travel up that great diagonal of color and smoke. You’re standing before Eugène Delacroix’s Liberty Leading the People, painted in the autumn of 1830, straight out of the chaos of the July Revolution in Paris. For three days, barricades went up, the people rose, and King Charles X fell. Delacroix didn’t fight in the streets, but he wrote to his brother, “If I haven’t fought for my country, at least I’ll paint for her.” This is that painting—a modern history picture charged like a live wire.

Start from the ground: the foreground is a tangle of bodies and broken weapons, painted in earthy browns and ashy grays. It’s not neat; it’s the unvarnished cost of revolt. From that heap rises a wedge of humanity—workers, students, citizens—surging forward. The composition is pyramidal: the base is those fallen figures, and at the apex strides Liberty herself, barefoot, bare-breasted like an ancient goddess, but wearing the red Phrygian cap of revolution. She hoists the tricolor—blue, white, red—which also organizes the painting’s palette. Look how those three colors echo everywhere, from the flag to the clothing to the sky’s smoky light. Delacroix turns patriotic color into atmosphere.

To Liberty’s right, there’s a young street boy, a gamin, brandishing pistols with wild energy—his wide-open mouth practically shouts. He’s become a symbol of youthful courage and would later echo in Victor Hugo’s character Gavroche. On her left, notice the man in the black top hat and dark coat, rifle in hand and cartridge bag slung across his shoulder. Many believe that’s Delacroix himself, folded into the crowd as a bourgeois citizen—elegant, determined, and very much part of the action.

Now let your gaze drift to the horizon. Through the haze of gunpowder, you can make out the twin towers of Notre-Dame. There’s even a tiny tricolor fluttering from it—a quiet pinpoint that anchors this scene in Paris and in a very specific moment in time. It’s easy to miss, but once you see it, the city snaps into place.

The whole thing is a study in motion and meaning. Liberty is an allegory, yes, but she’s also dusty, solid, striding over the barricade like someone you could reach out and touch. Delacroix fuses the timeless—classical bodies, heroic composition—with the urgent now of a modern uprising. That blend was risky. The state bought the painting after the 1831 Salon, then hid it away at times when its revolutionary fervor felt a little too contagious.

As you look, think of how images can crystallize a moment and also outlive it. This isn’t a tidy victory picture; it’s a picture of becoming—of citizens discovering themselves in the act of pushing forward. Delacroix gives us not just an event but a feeling: the terrifying, exhilarating instant when an idea—liberty—steps off the pedestal and walks among people. That’s why it still feels like it’s moving, even now, even here, as the air seems to tremble and the flag keeps catching the light.
stops.artistTranscript:
If you’re meeting Eugène Delacroix for the first time, think of him as the beating heart of French Romanticism. Born in 1798 just outside Paris and active through the mid-1800s, he made his name by choosing color, movement, and emotion over tidy outlines and cool logic. Where his great rival Ingres worshiped line, Delacroix chased atmosphere—the shimmer of light on skin, the rush of a crowd, the drama of a story mid‑flight.

He burst onto the scene young, with daring canvases drawn from literature and current events, and almost immediately stirred debate. Critics were split: was this passionate brushwork genius or chaos? Delacroix didn’t flinch. He studied the Venetian colorists and Rubens at the Louvre, traveled to London to absorb Shakespeare and English painting, and filled notebooks with experiments. Then came a pivotal journey in 1832 to North Africa. In Morocco and Algeria he sketched riders, textiles, and sun‑drenched courtyards—images that expanded his palette and fed works like Women of Algiers and a lifelong fascination with horses and big‑cat hunts.

All of that—the love of theater, the embrace of the present, the fearless color—flows into the painting you’ve just heard about. Delacroix believed history painting didn’t have to be remote or marble‑cold; it could be urgent, modern, and human. He painted like a composer, orchestrating tone and rhythm so that feeling leads the eye.

Despite the early storms, France eventually entrusted him with major public commissions: sweeping murals for the Palais Bourbon and the Palais du Luxembourg, the glowing ceiling in the Louvre’s Galerie d’Apollon, and the powerful chapel at Saint‑Sulpice. Writers and artists rallied to him—Baudelaire called him the most original painter of his age—and generations after, Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh, and Matisse mined his color for their own revolutions. He’s remembered not just for what he painted, but for showing painters that color could carry meaning all by itself. As he liked to say, the first merit of a picture is to be a feast for the eye.

One charming sidelight: Delacroix was close to musicians and writers, and he began a double portrait of Frédéric Chopin and George Sand on the same canvas. It was never finished and later cut in two—the Chopin half now in the Louvre, the Sand half in Ordrupgaard near Copenhagen—like a duet separated into solos.

If you picture Delacroix the man, imagine a reserved, elegant Parisian who filled quiet hours with a fiercely kept journal, then stepped into the studio to wrestle storms onto canvas. He wasn’t painting spectacles for the sake of noise; he was painting to make you feel alive. That’s the conversation he still invites us into today.

stops.title: The Oath of the Horatii — Jacques-Louis David
stops.description: Severe Neoclassical drama: duty, stoicism, and the birth of a civic ideal.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take a small step back with me and let your eyes take in the sweep of this canvas. It’s huge—almost stage-sized—and that’s no accident. Jacques-Louis David painted The Oath of the Horatii in 1784, in Rome, on a royal commission from Louis XVI’s arts administration. When it was shown at the Paris Salon the next year, it caused a sensation. The story comes from the Roman historian Livy: to avoid a full-scale war, Rome and its neighbor Alba Longa choose three champions each—the Horatii and the Curiatii—to fight to the death. David chose the moment before the clash, when duty is pledged and fate is sealed.

Look straight into the middle under those three stone arches—David builds the composition like a theater set. At the center, the father of the Horatii stands firm, legs braced, arms thrust forward, holding three swords like a fan. Facing him, the three brothers extend their right arms in a synchronized oath. Everything on the left is crisp, straight, and angular: bold outlines, hard light, polished armor. The colors are sober and Roman—iron grays, stone browns, a blaze of red that drives your eye to the center. You can almost hear the metal ring.

Now slide your gaze to the right. The mood collapses. The women sink into draped curves, their bodies folding in grief. One is the sister of the Horatii, another is married to a Curiatius—either way, love and family are about to be torn apart. A small child buries a face into a shawl; an older woman turns inward. David sets up a moral drama: public duty, straight-backed and lit like a monument, versus private sorrow, softened and shadowed. Even the architecture joins in—three arches, three brothers, three swords, a whole world organized into uncompromising triads.

A fun detail while you’re here: the very gesture of the oath—those outstretched arms—was essentially David’s invention. It’s not described like this in ancient sources. He created a clear, legible sign for civic commitment, one that would echo through the revolutionary years to come. And if you look closely at the floor tiles, the perspective lines funnel you right to the clash of hands and steel—David’s way of saying: this pledge is the point.

David was the great standard-bearer of Neoclassicism—clean lines, antique costume, moral seriousness—but the painting’s power isn’t just style. It asks a timeless question: when ideals demand sacrifice, what happens to the people who love us? That tension—between what we owe the state, and what we owe one another—keeps the canvas alive. As you step away, carry that double heartbeat with you: the ring of the oath on the left, and the quiet, very human sob on the right.
stops.artistTranscript:
Meet Jacques-Louis David: born in Paris in 1748, he became the defining voice of Neoclassicism—the movement that swapped rococo frills for crisp lines, clear storytelling, and big moral stakes. He trained at the Royal Academy, won the coveted Prix de Rome, and came back from Italy convinced that art should be as disciplined as a Roman legion and as persuasive as a great speech. His canvases look carved rather than painted: strong drawing, sculptural light, and a belief that history painting could shape character—and even politics.

David was intense, methodical, and a bit theatrical. A facial growth left him with a speech impediment, so he often let images do the talking. He choreographed bodies like a director, staging scenes so their meaning would read instantly. When he painted The Oath of the Horatii, he wasn’t just creating a picture; he was announcing a mission: art that asks citizens to choose virtue over comfort.

And David didn’t stop at the studio door. As the Revolution erupted, he stepped into the thick of it—elected a deputy to the National Convention, a close ally of Robespierre, organizer of state funerals and vast civic festivals, and he cast a decisive vote for the execution of Louis XVI. He painted martyrs of the cause, was imprisoned after Robespierre’s fall, and, on his release, tried to heal wounds with images of reconciliation. A few years later, he became Napoleon’s chief image-maker, crafting the unforgettable theater of power you see in The Coronation of Napoleon and Napoleon Crossing the Alps. If you picture the Revolution or the Empire, chances are you’re picturing it through David’s eye.

His studio was a powerhouse. Generations learned under him—Gros, Gérard, Girodet, and a young Ingres among them—so his insistence on drawing, clarity, and moral purpose shaped European art well into the 19th century.

One revealing epilogue: after Napoleon fell, David chose exile in Brussels because, as a regicide, he wasn’t welcome back. He died there in 1825. Paris, however, couldn’t quite let him go—his heart was later returned and buried at Père Lachaise, while the rest of him remains in Brussels. It’s a strangely fitting split for a man divided between private life and public destiny.

As you think about him, don’t see only a stern classicist. See someone who believed pictures could steady a shaken world, who lived through the turmoil he painted, and who asked—quietly but firmly—for courage, clarity, and conscience from anyone standing before his work.

stops.title: The Coronation of Napoleon — Jacques-Louis David
stops.description: Vast state spectacle captured with theatrical precision and political symbolism.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take a step back and let your eyes adjust—this thing is huge. You’re standing before Jacques-Louis David’s The Coronation of Napoleon, painted between 1805 and 1807. David was Napoleon’s official painter and the leading voice of Neoclassicism—clean lines, ancient Roman references, and lots of moral theater. Napoleon commissioned this monumental canvas to memorialize and legitimize his new empire by turning a single day—December 2, 1804, in Notre-Dame Cathedral—into a timeless epic.

Start in the center. Napoleon stands tall, laurel wreath on his head like a Roman emperor, arm lifted as he crowns Joséphine. Notice the choice: he isn’t crowning himself here—though he famously did—David freezes the gentler moment when he crowns his wife. Joséphine kneels in gleaming white satin and ermine, her train rippling like a river of light, held by ladies of honor. The whole scene glows with reds, golds, and ivory, while the cool stone of the cathedral anchors it in solemn grandeur.

Now look just behind Napoleon: Pope Pius VII sits quietly, hand raised in blessing. He’s there, but not in charge; the painter makes that perfectly clear. The diagonals of light, the curve of the figures, even the great crimson canopy—all sweep your eye to Napoleon and Joséphine. It’s ceremony as theater, choreographed to proclaim, “A new Rome is born.”

Let your gaze drift left to the balcony. In the most prominent seat sits Letizia Bonaparte, Napoleon’s mother—Madame Mère—composed and dignified. Here’s a delicious bit of truth: she didn’t attend the ceremony. David added her at Napoleon’s request, a reminder that paintings can rewrite memory as effectively as they record it.

Everywhere you look, symbols whisper empire: the golden eagles, the classical laurel, and those tiny embroidered bees on Napoleon’s mantle—an ancient emblem Napoleon adopted to suggest continuity with a venerable past. The architecture gives you sturdy verticals; the figures arrange into stately horizontals; and light pours in like a blessing, making this feel both intimate and colossal.

One more detail for you: in the right-hand gallery, David tucked in a self-portrait among the spectators—a quiet signature in the crowd. He staged endless sittings, brought people into his studio in full regalia, and even redesigned reality when it served the story. That’s part of the brilliance here: the painting doesn’t just show power, it manufactures it.

As you take it in, think of how images like this shape what we remember. David, the great dramatist of the French Revolution and the Empire, turns politics into pageant and pageant into history. Whether you admire Napoleon or raise an eyebrow at his self-mythmaking, this canvas reminds us that art can crown a moment—and sometimes, make it eternal.
stops.artistTranscript:
Before we leave Napoleon’s big moment, meet the mind that staged it: Jacques-Louis David. Born in Paris in 1748, trained in Rome in his twenties, David became the defining painter of Neoclassicism—clear contours, sculptural light, and stories lifted from antiquity to talk about courage, duty, and public virtue. He wasn’t just a stylist; he was a believer in the power of images to shape citizens.

His climb was classic and hard-won. After early studies with the Rococo master François Boucher and then Joseph-Marie Vien, he won the Prix de Rome in 1774 and soaked up ancient art in Italy. Back in Paris, he turned moral drama into blockbuster painting—think The Oath of the Horatii and The Death of Socrates—works that made viewers feel that virtue had a spine of steel.

Then history rushed in. During the French Revolution, David stepped out of the studio and into politics. He served as a deputy in the National Convention, aligned with the Jacobins, voted for the execution of Louis XVI, and even designed the vast civic festivals that turned republican ideals into public theater. After the fall of Robespierre, he was imprisoned, then rebuilt his career with pictures about reconciliation and, soon, with the visual language of a new regime.

That brings us back to why he was the right painter for an imperial spectacle. David thought like a director. He believed drawing was discipline, gesture was grammar, and a canvas could choreograph civic feeling. By the time he worked for Napoleon, he had decades of practice turning ceremony into history—anchoring emotion in rigor, and politics in form.

His legacy is everywhere in 19th-century art. He ran the most influential studio in Paris, training painters like Gros, Gérard, Girodet, and Ingres. Whether they stayed loyal to his severity or rebelled against it, they all learned to think with the line before they painted with color.

One detail people love: David lived his whole life with a tumor on his cheek that made speaking difficult. Yet the man who struggled for words could command a room with a glance—and orchestrate nations with images.

David died in exile in Brussels in 1825, barred from returning because he had voted for the king’s death. His body stayed in Belgium, but years later his heart was interred in Paris—a fitting symbol for an artist whose passions were always tied to his city. As you move on, keep him in mind not just as a painter of heroes, but as a citizen-artist who believed art could build the world he wanted to live in.

stops.title: Galerie d’Apollon (Crown Jewels) — Room Stop
stops.description: A dazzling, gilded gallery; walk the length and pause at the Crown Jewels cases.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take a breath and look up. You’re standing in the Galerie d’Apollon—a soaring, golden avenue of light. This room was born from both disaster and ambition: after a fire in 1661, Louis XIV, the “Sun King,” ordered a new gallery worthy of his image. Architect Louis Le Vau designed it; Charles Le Brun, the king’s chief painter, devised the grand program celebrating Apollo, the sun god—Louis’s celestial alter ego. The sculpted stuccoes you see, all swirling laurels, lyres, and sunbursts, were executed by masters like François Girardon. The project paused when the court decamped to Versailles, and the gallery remained incomplete for centuries. In the 1850s it finally received its dramatic centerpiece: look to the vault’s heart to spot Eugène Delacroix’s Apollo Slaying the Python—Apollo’s arrow cutting through shadow, the serpent recoiling in a burst of movement and color.

Now let your eyes come down to the cases. Here are the Crown Jewels of France—glittering survivors of revolution, empire, and auction block. Front and center is the Regent diamond, an exceptionally pure, 140-carat stone from India. It once sparkled in Louis XV’s crown and, most famously, was set into the hilt of Napoleon’s ceremonial sword. Nearby is the Sancy, a pale lemon diamond with an unusual, symmetrical cut that catches light like a heartbeat. And don’t miss the peach-tinged Hortensia, named for Hortense de Beauharnais, Napoleon’s stepdaughter—a soft blush of color amidst the icy brilliants.

You’ll also see crowns that tell a twisty tale. The elegant crown of Empress Eugénie—Second Empire grandeur in diamonds and emeralds—survives almost as it was. But Louis XV’s coronation crown is a splendid illusion: the original jewels were sold off in 1885, so what you’re admiring now is the original gold mount sparkling with carefully cut glass. It’s a reminder that the glory of a crown is as much about craftsmanship and symbolism as about carats.

A little detail to hunt for: in the gilded décor above, look for Apollo’s attributes tucked into the ornament—tiny lyres and laurel wreaths woven into the scrollwork. And up in Delacroix’s painting, notice how the coils of the Python echo the curving stucco frames around it, binding 17th- and 19th-century artistry into one continuous drama.

Before we move on, a thought: this gallery is often called a forerunner to the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles. You can feel why—the sheer theater of it. But unlike Versailles, here the performance isn’t just royal power; it’s resilience. These jewels were stolen during the Revolution, many were dispersed, and yet some returned. The room itself took two centuries to complete. Standing here, you’re seeing how art, myth, and history don’t move in straight lines—they spiral, like that serpent—only to resolve, at last, in light.
stops.artistTranscript:
Meet Eugène Delacroix: born in 1798, raised around Paris, and the fiery heart of French Romanticism. Where earlier painters prized line and polish, Delacroix championed color, movement, and emotion. He trained in the studio of Pierre-Narcisse Guérin, but his real teachers were Rubens and the Venetian masters, whose lush color and sweeping rhythms he studied obsessively. He made his name with bold Salon canvases that shocked some critics and thrilled others, and over time he became the go-to artist for grand public decorations across Paris.

Delacroix wasn’t just a dramatist—he was a consummate craftsman. He kept meticulous journals, tested pigments like a chemist, and thought about painting the way his friends in music thought about orchestration: harmonies, contrasts, crescendos. A key turning point came in 1832, when he traveled to Morocco and Algeria with a diplomatic mission. The light, textiles, and horsemen he sketched there exploded his palette; those saturated reds, golds, and deep blues echo through his work for the rest of his life.

That blend of discipline and daring is what he brought to this very gallery. Imagine the challenge: stepping into a space already shaped by 17th-century splendor and finding a way to make it sing anew. Delacroix mapped his composition carefully, scaled it to the architecture, and then unleashed his trademark energy—muscular figures, charged diagonals, and color that feels lit from within. It’s a Romantic voice conversing respectfully, but confidently, with the grand tradition around it.

His influence reaches far beyond this room. Later artists—from Manet to Monet, from Cézanne to Matisse—learned from his fearless color and free brushwork. He faced plenty of headwinds: fierce debates with classicists like Ingres, bouts of ill health, and the heartbreak of seeing some of his Paris decorations lost in the 1871 fires. Yet he kept working, was finally elected to the Académie des Beaux-Arts, and left Paris studded with his murals.

One detail I love: Delacroix often slipped away to the Jardin des Plantes to sketch lions and tigers. Those studies of coiled muscle and sudden movement fed the urgency you feel in his mythic scenes.

As you look around, remember the man behind the thunder: elegant, reserved, endlessly curious—someone who believed that color could carry feeling straight to the heart, and who poured that conviction into every inch he painted.

stops.title: Mona Lisa (La Gioconda) — Leonardo da Vinci
stops.description: The world’s most famous portrait—visit strategically at the end to manage crowd flow.
stops.artworkTranscript:
Take a slow step closer and let your eyes settle. You’re face to face with perhaps the most familiar stranger in art: Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa, also known as La Gioconda. Leonardo began this portrait in Florence around 1503, very likely portraying Lisa Gherardini, the wife of the merchant Francesco del Giocondo. He kept working on it for years—Leonardo was famously reluctant to call a masterpiece “finished”—and he eventually brought it with him to France when he entered the service of King Francis I in 1516. After Leonardo’s death in 1519, it entered the French royal collection, and that’s how it comes to be here today.

What you’re looking at is surprisingly intimate—smaller than most people expect. It’s oil on a poplar wood panel, a half-length figure turned slightly toward you, hands folded with relaxed dignity. The composition builds a gentle pyramid: head at the apex, shoulders and hands forming the base. There’s no showy jewelry, no heraldic background—just a woman, calmly present. Her dress is dark and simple, topped with a fine, transparent veil at her hairline and over her shoulders, a detail many visitors miss.

Now let your gaze wander to the landscape behind her. It’s not a real place, but a dreamlike world of winding roads, a tiny arched bridge, water that seems to pool and fall away, and mountains fading into bluish haze. Leonardo uses atmospheric perspective so distances dissolve into cool blues and greens. Notice how the horizon sits a touch higher on one side than the other—an almost imperceptible imbalance that adds to the painting’s quiet sense of motion.

And then, her expression. That famous smile lives in the soft transitions—the sfumato—that smoky layering of glazes around her mouth and eyes. Look straight at the smile and it seems to retreat; glance slightly away and it blooms again. It isn’t a trick so much as Leonardo understanding how our eyes perceive gentle shadows. Her gaze feels alive because the modeling is so subtle that your brain keeps completing it anew.

A couple of hidden treats: at the very edges you can spot the bases of two columns, reminders that she once sat in a loggia. And if you’ve heard she has no eyebrows—under magnification, faint traces do appear. They’re not a fashion statement so much as the result of delicate paint and centuries of cleaning and varnish.

Fun fact: in 1911 this painting was stolen—lifted right off the wall and spirited away for two years. The theft made headlines worldwide and, ironically, helped turn Mona Lisa into a global celebrity when she was recovered.

Before you move on, take one more look. Portraits often try to pin a person down; Leonardo does the opposite. He gives you presence, not a pose—an encounter that changes as you do. Across five centuries, in a handful of quiet browns and cool blues, he reminds us how much mystery can live in a human face—and how art can keep that mystery alive, one curious glance at a time.
stops.artistTranscript:
If the Renaissance had a poster child for curiosity, it would be Leonardo da Vinci. Born in 1452 in the Tuscan town of Vinci, he trained in Florence and spent many of his most productive years in Milan. He wasn’t just a painter—he was an engineer, stage designer, anatomist, architect, and tireless note-taker. What makes him stand out is how he wove art and science together: he painted with the same questions he brought to flying machines, canal systems, and anatomy labs.

In Milan, working for the Sforza court, he planned festivals and fortifications and painted major works like The Last Supper—brilliant in design, but made with an experimental technique that began to deteriorate early, a reminder that his appetite for innovation could come with risks. His drawing we now call the Vitruvian Man, that figure in a circle and square, shows how deeply he searched for harmony between the human body and the geometry of the world.

Leonardo studied how we see—light bouncing off water, haze softening distant hills, the way eyelids and lips rise and fall with the tiniest muscle shifts. He dissected human bodies to understand the structure beneath the skin and filled notebooks with observations written in his left-handed mirror script. One line from a to-do list captures him perfectly: “Describe the tongue of the woodpecker.” That’s Leonardo—endlessly precise, endlessly curious.

Bring that back to the portrait you’ve just seen. The quiet lifelikeness people respond to isn’t an accident; it grows from his habit of watching patiently until the smallest transitions of light and form felt truthful. He cared less about pomp and more about presence—about catching the moment a thought crosses a face.

He could be famously slow, often leaving commissions unfinished, which frustrated patrons. And yet his legacy is enormous: generations of artists adopted his gentle modeling and atmospheric depth, while scientists and engineers still marvel at his anatomical drawings and ingenious machines. After his death, his student Francesco Melzi preserved many of those papers, which is why we can still read his restless mind today.

As you move on, keep this in mind: Leonardo wasn’t chasing perfection so much as understanding. The painting you met is a trace of a person who asked better questions every year of his life—and invites us to do the same.
